snippet: The increasing application of antimonopoly laws, against companies like Microsoft and Qualcomm, has raised concern in boardrooms around the world.
abstract: China's increasing application of antimonopoly laws, targeting companies like Microsoft and Qualcomm, is raising concern in boardrooms around the world; foreign companies fear they could become easy targets for officials from array of competing agencies and local governments aiming to impress Pres Xi Jinping.

byline.original: By NEIL GOUGH, CHRIS BUCKLEY and NICK WINGFIELD
byline.contributor: Neil Gough and Chris Buckley reported from Hong Kong and Nick Wingfield from Seattle. Quentin Hardy contributed reporting from San Francisco.

lead_paragraph: The increasing application of antimonopoly laws, against companies like Microsoft and Qualcomm, has raised concern in boardrooms around the world.

headline.main: China’s Energetic Enforcement of Antitrust Rules Alarms Foreign Firms
headline.print_headline: China’s Energetic Enforcement of Antitrust Rules Alarms Foreign Firms

keywords.value: State Administration for Industry and Commerce (China)
keywords.name: organizations
